channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [TIKA-4091] OLE2 / CFB entry names should be treated case-insensitively
item.description:
According to section 2.6.1 of MS-CFB, entries (whether they be "storage" or "stream" nodes) should be located with a special case-insensitive uppercase mapping. I believe Tika is using a case-sensitive approach, e.g. when looking for certain OLE2 objects in POIFSContainerDetector.java. The result is that Tika may perform incomplete or otherwise subpar type detection on OLE2 files, as well as provide incomplete metadata & extracted text output.

Attached are some sample documents. The 3 "simple" ones demonstrate incomplete metadata & text extraction. These 3 files are equivalent except for the casing of the OLE2 names. Word opens all normally and shows the correct metadata. Tika output is missing all metadata and document content for the "upper case" and "lower case" variants.

The two "protected" examples are again equivalent, except for the casing. Tika gives an EncryptedDocumentException for "protected - normal case.docx" but not for "protected - upper case.docx". The password for these 2 files is "password".
item.summary: OLE2 / CFB entry names should be treated case-insensitively

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Thank you for opening this. We can fix a few things on the Tika side, but POI is case-sensitive throughout.  For example, I get this exception trying to open the "*- upper case.doc" example file:

 

Caused by: java.io.FileNotFoundException: no such entry: "WordDocument", had: [�SUMMARYINFORMATION, �COMPOBJ, DATA, 1TABLE, WORDDOCUMENT, �DOCUMENTSUMMARYINFORMATION]
    at org.apache.poi.poifs.filesystem.DirectoryNode.getEntry(DirectoryNode.java:338)
    at org.apache.poi.hwpf.HWPFDocumentCore.getDocumentEntryBytes(HWPFDocumentCore.java:340)
    at org.apache.poi.hwpf.HWPFDocumentCore.<init>(HWPFDocumentCore.java:184)
    at org.apache.poi.hwpf.HWPFDocument.<init>(HWPFDocument.java:253)
    at org.apache.tika.parser.microsoft.WordExtractor.parse(WordExtractor.java:155)
    at org.apache.tika.parser.microsoft.OfficeParser.parse(OfficeParser.java:220)
    at org.apache.tika.parser.microsoft.OfficeParser.parse(OfficeParser.java:177)
    at org.apache.tika.parser.CompositeParser.parse(CompositeParser.java:298)

 

The only solution that comes to mind would be a fairly substantial refactoring of POI to handle finding entries in a case-insensitive way.  Perhaps open an issue on POI's bugzilla?

https://bz.apache.org/bugzilla/describecomponents.cgi?product=POI

Thanks for your contribution to [Apache Tika](https://tika.apache.org/)! Your help is appreciated!

Before opening the pull request, please verify that

  • there is an open issue on the [Tika issue tracker](https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/TIKA) which describes the problem or the improvement. We cannot accept pull requests without an issue because the change wouldn't be listed in the release notes.
  • the issue ID (`TIKA-XXXX`)
  • is referenced in the title of the pull request
  • and placed in front of your commit messages surrounded by square brackets (`[TIKA-XXXX] Issue or pull request title`)
  • commits are squashed into a single one (or few commits for larger changes)
  • Tika is successfully built and unit tests pass by running `mvn clean test`
  • there should be no conflicts when merging the pull request branch into the recent `main` branch. If there are conflicts, please try to rebase the pull request branch on top of a freshly pulled `main` branch
  • if you add new module that downstream users will depend upon add it to relevant group in `tika-bom/pom.xml`.

We will be able to faster integrate your pull request if these conditions are met. If you have any questions how to fix your problem or about using Tika in general, please sign up for the [Tika mailing list](http://tika.apache.org/mail-lists.html). Thanks!

Thanks for pointing me to the bugzilla tracker. Looking now, I do see an existing POI issue https://bz.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=47950.

For further context, this is not purely academic as I have seen some of these docs "in the wild" but I don't have a good idea of how prevalent they are or what software generates the unusual cases. I can try to run some checks and see how common this type of file might be.

14 years ago... <smh/> LOL...

 

I'll take a look over on POI.  fanningpj had a helpful suggestion for implementation: https://lists.apache.org/thread/n9kw962zs5y1mk8rpd3v8x253stkvx67

The recent regression tests in preparation for the next release revealed quite a few, erm, surprises. The reports are here: https://corpora.tika.apache.org/base/reports/tika-2.8.1-prerc1-b.tgz

The concerning part is the number of missing attachments. I found that one cause is OCX (active x controls) are now getting detected as a package instead of OLE2. I'll push a fix for that and then we can see if there are any other surprises.
Better, but still some areas for improvement: https://corpora.tika.apache.org/base/reports/tika-2.8.1-pre-rc1-msoffice.tgz
I made one more change locally, and I'm running the regression tests now.

tballison merged PR #1286:
URL: https://github.com/apache/tika/pull/1286

I made a small change that will improve some edge cases. TIKA-4116 will likely dramatically change the number of attachments. So we won't easily be able to identify diffs.

There were "missing" macro attachments in: https://corpora.tika.apache.org/base/docs/govdocs1/527/527356.doc but that problem evaporates when we fix the duplication bug.

For posterity, the issue for the missing ones was that there were now getting identified as OLE comp objs (because they had a comp obj string and "contents" – notice the case), whereas before they were getting identified as OLE because there was no case sensitive "Contents" entry. When they get identified as OLE, our macro extractor runs on the root's filesystem, which means that these were incorrectly triggering multiple runs of macro extraction.

SUCCESS: Integrated in Jenkins build Tika » tika-main-jdk11 #1206 (See https://ci-builds.apache.org/job/Tika/job/tika-main-jdk11/1206/)
